title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement max@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

what: Prior-Data Fitted Network Foundational Model for Tabular Data
title: Prior-Data Fitted Network Foundational Model for Tabular Data
text: tabpfn, meaning prior fitted networks tabular data, deep-learning model. See: Transformers Can Bayesian Inference (arXiv, 2021) TabPFN: Transformer Solves Small Tabular Classification Problems Second (arXiv, 2022) Accurate predictions small data tabular foundation model (Nature, 2025) R package wrapper Python library via reticulate. idiomatic R syntax using standard S3 methods.

title: Prior-Data Fitted Network Foundational Model for Tabular Data
text: can install development version tabpfn like : ’ll need Python virtual environment access underlying library. installing R package, tabpfn install required Python bits first fit model:
code: require(pak) pak(c("tidymodels/tabpfn"), ask = FALSE) > library(tabpfn) > > predictors <- mtcars[, -1] > outcome <- mtcars[, 1] > > # XY interface > mod <- tab_pfn(predictors, outcome) Downloading uv...Done! Downloading cpython-3.12.12 (download) (15.9MiB)  Downloading cpython-3.12.12 (download) Downloading setuptools (1.1MiB) Downloading scikit-learn (8.2MiB) Downloading numpy (4.9MiB)  <downloading and installing more packages>   Downloading llvmlite  Downloading torch Installed 58 packages in 350ms > mod tabpfn Regression Model  Training set i 32 data points i 10 predictors

title: Prior-Data Fitted Network Foundational Model for Tabular Data
text: fit model: addition x/y interface shown , also formula recipes interfaces. Prediction follows usual S3 predict() method: tabpfn follows tidymodels prediction convention: data frame always returned standard set column names. classification model, outcome always factor vector. example, using data modeldata package: fit looks fairly good shown --sample data:
code: library(tabpfn) reg_mod <- tab_pfn(mtcars[1:25, -1], mtcars$mpg[1:25]) reg_mod #> TabPFN Regression Model #> Training set #> ℹ 25 data points #> ℹ 10 predictors predict(reg_mod, mtcars[26:32, -1]) #> # A tibble: 7 × 1 #>   .pred #>   <dbl> #> 1  29.9 #> 2  25.5 #> 3  25.2 #> 4  15.8 #> 5  18.8 #> 6  14.5 #> 7  23.7 library(modeldata) #>  #> Attaching package: 'modeldata' #> The following object is masked from 'package:datasets': #>  #>     penguins library(ggplot2)  two_cls_train <- parabolic[1:400,  ] two_cls_val   <- parabolic[401:500,] grid <- expand.grid(X1 = seq(-5.1, 5.0, length.out = 25),                      X2 = seq(-5.5, 4.0, length.out = 25))  cls_mod <- tab_pfn(class ~ ., data = two_cls_train)  grid_pred <- predict(cls_mod, grid) grid_pred #> # A tibble: 625 × 3 #>    .pred_Class1 .pred_Class2 .pred_class #>           <dbl>        <dbl> <fct>       #>  1        0.987      0.0129  Class1      #>  2        0.991      0.00920 Class1      #>  3        0.994      0.00633 Class1      #>  4        0.994      0.00609 Class1      #>  5        0.991      0.00879 Class1      #>  6        0.986      0.0144  Class1      #>  7        0.970      0.0304  Class1      #>  8        0.927      0.0733  Class1      #>  9        0.813      0.187   Class1      #> 10        0.538      0.462   Class1      #> # ℹ 615 more rows cbind(grid, grid_pred) |>  ggplot(aes(X1, X2)) +   geom_point(data = two_cls_val, aes(col = class, pch = class),              alpha = 3 / 4, cex = 3) +  geom_contour(aes(z = .pred_Class1), breaks = 1/ 2, col = "black", linewidth = 1) +  coord_equal(ratio = 1)

title: Controlling TabPFN execution — control_tab_pfn
text: Controlling TabPFN execution

title: Controlling TabPFN execution — control_tab_pfn
code: control_tab_pfn(   n_preprocessing_jobs = 1L,   device = "auto",   ignore_pretraining_limits = FALSE,   inference_precision = "auto",   fit_mode = "fit_preprocessors",   memory_saving_mode = "auto",   random_state = sample.int(10^6, 1) )

title: Controlling TabPFN execution — control_tab_pfn
text: n_preprocessing_jobs integer number worker processes. value -1L indicates possible resources. device character value device used torch (e.g., "cpu", "cuda", "mps", etc.). Th default "auto". ignore_pretraining_limits logical bypass default data limits :number training set samples (10,000) , number predictors (500). unchangeable limit number classes (10). inference_precision character value trade speed reproducibility. can torch dtype, "autocast" (torch's mixed-precision autocast), "auto". fit_mode character value control preprocessed /cached. Values "fit_preprocessors" (default), "low_memory", "fit_with_cache", "batched". memory_saving_mode character string help --memory errors. Values either logical "auto". random_state integer set random number stream.

title: Controlling TabPFN execution — control_tab_pfn
text: https://github.com/PriorLabs/TabPFN/blob/main/src/tabpfn/classifier.py, https://github.com/PriorLabs/TabPFN/blob/main/src/tabpfn/regressor.py

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: tab_pfn() applies data pre-estimated deep learning model defined Hollmann et al (2025). model emulates Bayesian inference regression classification models.

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
code: tab_pfn(x, ...)  # Default S3 method tab_pfn(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'data.frame' tab_pfn(   x,   y,   num_estimators = 8L,   softmax_temperature = 0.9,   balance_probabilities = FALSE,   average_before_softmax = FALSE,   training_set_limit = 10000,   control = control_tab_pfn(),   ... )  # S3 method for class 'matrix' tab_pfn(   x,   y,   num_estimators = 8L,   softmax_temperature = 0.9,   balance_probabilities = FALSE,   average_before_softmax = FALSE,   training_set_limit = 10000,   control = control_tab_pfn(),   ... )  # S3 method for class 'formula' tab_pfn(   formula,   data,   num_estimators = 8L,   softmax_temperature = 0.9,   balance_probabilities = FALSE,   average_before_softmax = FALSE,   training_set_limit = 10000,   control = control_tab_pfn(),   ... )  # S3 method for class 'recipe' tab_pfn(   x,   data,   num_estimators = 8L,   softmax_temperature = 0.9,   balance_probabilities = FALSE,   average_before_softmax = FALSE,   training_set_limit = 10000,   control = control_tab_pfn(),   ... )

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: x Depending context: data frame predictors. matrix predictors. recipe specifying set preprocessing steps created recipes::recipe(). ... currently used, required extensibility. y x data frame matrix, y outcome specified : data frame 1 numeric column. matrix 1 numeric column. numeric vector regression factor classification. num_estimators integer ensemble size. Default 8L. softmax_temperature adjustment factor divisor exponents softmax function (see Details ). Defaults 0.9. balance_probabilities logical adjust prior probabilities cases class imbalance. Default FALSE. Classification . average_before_softmax logical. cases num_estimators > 1, average done using softmax function ? Default FALSE. training_set_limit integer greater 2L (possibly Inf) can used keep training data within limits data constraints imposed Python library. control list options produced control_tab_pfn(). formula formula specifying outcome terms left-hand side, predictor terms right-hand side. data recipe formula used, data specified : data frame containing predictors outcome.

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: tab_pfn object elements: fit: python object containing model. levels: character string class levels (NULL regression) training: vector training set dimensions. logging: R python messages produced computations. blueprint: object produced hardhat::mold() used process new data prediction.

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: model can used without graphics processing unit (GPU). However, fairly limited used CPU (GPU). might additional data size limitation warnings CPU computations, , understandably, execution time much longer. CPU computations can also consume significant amount system memory, depending size data. GPUs using CUDA (Compute Unified Device Architecture) effective. Limited testing others shown GPUs Metal Performance Shaders (MPS) instructions (e.g., Apple GPUs) limited utility specific computations might slower CPU data sets.

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: November 6, 2025, PriorLabs released version 2.5 model, contained several improvements. One change accessing model parameters required API key. Without one, error occurs: "model gated requires accept terms.  Please follow steps: 1. Visit https://huggingface.co/Prior-Labs/tabpfn_2_5 browser accept terms use. 2. Log Hugging Face account via command line running: hf auth login (Alternatively, can set HF_TOKEN environment variable read token)." license contains provisions "Non-Commercial Use " usage relevant . get API key, use huggingface link , create account, get API key. , put .Renviron file form : usethis function edit_r_environ() can helpful .

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: need working Python virtual environment correct packages use modeling functions. least two ways proceed.

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: first approach, strongly suggest, simply load package attempt run model. prompt reticulate create ephemeral environment automatically install required packages. process look like : location environment can found tools::R_user_dir("reticulate", "cache"). See documentation reticulate::py_require() learn method.
code: > library(tabpfn)   >   > predictors <- mtcars[, -1]   > outcome <- mtcars[, 1]   >   > # XY interface   > mod <- tab_pfn(predictors, outcome)   Downloading uv...Done!   Downloading cpython-3.12.12 (download) (15.9MiB)    Downloading cpython-3.12.12 (download)   Downloading setuptools (1.1MiB)   Downloading scikit-learn (8.2MiB)   Downloading numpy (4.9MiB)    <downloading and installing more packages>     Downloading llvmlite    Downloading torch   Installed 58 packages in 350ms   > mod   TabPFN Regression Model    Training set   i 32 data points   i 10 predictors

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: Alternatively, can use functions reticulate package create virtual environment install required Python packages . example pattern : virtual environment installed, can declare preferred Python installation use_virtualenv(). (must reticulate initialized Python, .e., attempting use tabpfn):
code: library(reticulate)    venv_name <- "r-tabpfn"    # exact name can be different   venv_seed_python <-     virtualenv_starter(">=3.11,<3.14")     virtualenv_create(     envname = venv_name,     python = venv_seed_python,     packages = c("numpy", "tabpfn")   ) reticulate::use_virtualenv("r-tabpfn")

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: default, limits training data dimensions: Version 2.0: number training set samples (10,000) , number predictors (500). unchangeable limit number classes (10). Version 2.5: number training set samples (50,000) , number predictors (2,000). unchangeable limit number classes (10). Predictors require preprocessing; missing values factor vectors allowed.

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: softmax_temperature value, softmax terms : value softmax_temperature = 1 results plain softmax value.

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
text: Hollmann, Noah, Samuel Müller, Lennart Purucker, Arjun Krishnakumar, Max Körfer, Shi Bin Hoo, Robin Tibor Schirrmeister, Frank Hutter. "Accurate predictions small data tabular foundation model." Nature 637, . 8045 (2025): 319-326. Hollmann, Noah, Samuel Müller, Katharina Eggensperger, Frank Hutter. "Tabpfn: transformer solves small tabular classification problems second." arXiv preprint arXiv:2207.01848 (2022). Müller, Samuel, Noah Hollmann, Sebastian Pineda Arango, Josif Grabocka, Frank Hutter. "Transformers can Bayesian inference." arXiv preprint arXiv:2112.10510 (2021).

title: Fit a TabPFN model. — tab_pfn
code: predictors <- mtcars[, -1] outcome <- mtcars[, 1]  if (is_tab_pfn_installed()) {  # XY interface  mod <- tab_pfn(predictors, outcome)   # Formula interface  mod2 <- tab_pfn(mpg ~ ., mtcars)   # Recipes interface  if (rlang::is_installed("recipes")) {   library(recipes)   rec <-    recipe(mpg ~ ., mtcars) %>%    step_log(disp)    mod3 <- tab_pfn(rec, mtcars)   mod3  } } #> Loading required package: dplyr #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union #>  #> Attaching package: ‘recipes’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     step #> TabPFN Regression Model #>  #> Training set #> ℹ 32 data points #> ℹ 10 predictors
